title.narrative: Enhanced Work Programme 2015 Liaison Office New York

description.narrative:
2015 signifies a crucial period in the work of UNIDO. The Director-General has already identified and the Board of Directors has discussed three key priorities to guide the work of the Organization during this critical period and beyond. These priorities are: 1. At the policy level, to promote the concept of ISID in the processes leading the formulation of the Post-2015 development agenda; 2. At the operational level, to align the services provided by UNIDO with the mandate given by the Lima Declaration, and to meet the emerging and diversified needs of Member States; 3. At the management level, to optimize UNIDO’s operations to ensure that they are carried out more efficiently and effectively.
As for the first priority, the process of formulating the Post-2015 agenda is now reaching its most critical stage. Based on the outcomes the Open Working Group on SDGs and various other inputs, including the Synthesis Report of the Secretary-General, the process is now firmly anchored in the inter-governmental negotiations at UN Headquarters in New York. This is where the outcome document and its main components (declaration, SDGs, Means of Implementation and Global Partnership, Review/monitoring mechanisms) will be negotiated for adoption by the Heads of States Summit during the General Assembly in September 2015. It is the place where UNIDO needs to influence discussions at this critical juncture.
As for the second priority, UNIDO will face the critical task of becoming “fit for purpose” to operationally deliver on elements of the Post-2015 development agenda directly related to the Organization’s Lima mandate – especially SDG 9 on “Building Resilient infrastructure, inclusive and sustainable industrialization and innovation”. Besides aligning its services to SDG 9, UNIDO will, first and foremost, need to position itself among Member States as the lead “implementing and monitoring agency” for the industrialization-part of SDG 9. This process may happen through UNIDO’s Governing Bodies at HQ in Vienna, but it will also have critical elements at UN HQ in New York. Ongoing debates including ECOSOC’s “Dialogue on the long-term position of the UN Development System” and the Quadrennial Comprehensive Policy Review (QCPR) will have to be influenced in the right direction.
In view of both priorities, UNIDO’s operations at UN Headquarters in New York are, therefore, expected to continue to assume a critical role during 2015. An enhanced work programme has, therefore, been designed to guide those operations and equip them with the necessary resources to effectively contribute to the achievement of both main priorities. Allocating these resources on the ground in New York will, coincidentally, contribute to advance the Director-General’s third main priority, i.e. optimizing efficiency and effectiveness of UNIDO’s operations.
